text: when i moved from one activity to another
com.example.myapp.Adapters.NoDataListViewAdapter.getView
that may be returning null
well no
that shouldn’t be it
you might be giving it the wrong resource id?
it works when i don't do regression testing . but if i test regressively like when i go back and forth in the activities
it crashes
which gives this error
so i am not giving wrong resourceId
For custom widget in xml you should write full class name, with package. For example <com.example.myapp.MyFancyWidget>.  Writing <MyFancyWidget> may cause error like this
yeah but that should cause a class not found error
maybe try the allocation tracker to follow it?
I see OutOfMemory exception at the end of the trace
i think he posted that exception before and something tried to allocate 43mb
got some serious gremlins in your code =P
any long-running or non-trivial method calls get triggered when you’re swapping activities/fragments?
yes .. when i switch between calls .. i make http call to api
you aren’t passing that the activity as context as you?
and you dont have callbacks in the activity that are not unregistering
activity/fragment
I have callbacks in activity/fragments and i am passing context as MyActivity.this
<@U055GGAHS>: <@U04U5KS3Z>
yeah that can be a pretty serious memory leak if you are not cleaning everything up as soon as the activity needs to go into onDestroy
How to clean everything ?
never pass an activity as context unless it is to a UI element
instead do getActivity().getApplicationContext()
past that, make sure you are unregistering your listeners
so anything that calls back to the activity that is not a UI element needs to forget the activity
ahh.. okay :simple_smile:

"never pass an activity as context unless it is to a UI element"
Oh... good to know.
that’s a general rule
there are cases where you do have to pass an activity to a non ui element
but 9/10 its a trap
<https://possiblemobile.com/2013/06/context/>

attachments.title: Context, What Context? - by Dave Smith of Double Encore
attachments.text: Context is a common object in the Android framework, but are you sure you're using it properly? There are different types of Context for different purposes.

<https://rammic.github.io/2015/07/28/hiding-secrets-in-android-apps/>
spends the whole article picking apart security measures and gives one sentence on how to protect against them :disappointed:
which is fine but… some people might read through all that and think they just shouldn’t bother securing anything at all
i think reading that you should conclude anything in your APK can be found and read
I reversed engineered so many apps, I just love it
but I have to say, it’s easy.
Damn too easy.
whenever i talk to someone about security they usually just like to play devil’s advocate: “well don’t do _that_, i could just do _this_” without many suggestions
i was optimistic when square came out with keywhiz but after reading through the docs a bit it feels like more of an enterprise solution
so until i have to protect the API key for the white house, i’m probably just using the “i don’t need to outrun the bear, i just need to outrun you” approach
I guess the question I have is the google play keys/IAP keys - what's everyone's approach to storing/handling it?
